newsitem.title: USA: McDonald's Arch Deluxe burger adds to sales.
newsitem.headline: McDonald's Arch Deluxe burger adds to sales.

text.p: McDonald's Corp said Wednesday its new Arch Deluxe hamburger, launched in the United States in May, continues to add to sales in the third quarter.
"We think Arch Deluxe added incrementally to sales in the second quarter, and we believe that continues to be true," Mary Healy, director of financial communications, said.

But analysts said the Arch Deluxe has not helped offset declines in McDonald's U.S. same store sales in July and August. Same-store sales have been hurt by the fast-food chain's rapid pace of expansion, they added.

Analysts said they estimated that same-store sales, which measure revenues from units open at least a year, fell by between two percent and four percent in July and did not improve in August. They blamed intense competition in the United States and the addition of new units.

"With virtually every new opening, you're encroaching on an existing unit," Schroder Wertheim analyst Wayne Daniels said. "They (McDonald's) would tell you that cannibalization (of sales of existing restaurants) costs about one percentage point" on same store sales.
Daniels added that McDonald's U.S. same-store sales have been flat to down since mid-1995.
Healy declined to comment specifically on U.S. sales and profits in the third quarter. But she reiterated McDonald's stance that comparable store sales are not the only measure of performance.
"McDonald's strategy is to go after market share on an aggressive basis," she said.
McDonald's has been trying to lure in more customers, especially adults, with its Arch Deluxe, a hamburger with lettuce, tomato and mustard-mayonnaise sauce on a soft roll.
Healy said that Oak Brook, Ill.-based McDonald's is pleased overall with Arch Deluxe, but did not give any sales figures.
"Customer acceptance is very high," she added.
Some analysts have questioned Arch Deluxe's abilty to draw new customers into McDonald's, adding the new hamburger may simply replace purchases of other menu offerings.
"We never suggested that we thought one product could make a...difference in the competitive U.S. environment," Healy said.
However, McDonald's has called the Arch Deluxe its biggest product introduction. In May, the company said it hoped the hamburger would reap $1 billion in sales the first year.
McDonald's said it continues to test deluxe versions of its chicken and fish sandwiches, focusing on the Fresno, Calif., and Cincinnati, Ohio markets.
"At some point there may be some more menu news," McDonald's spokesman Chuck Ebeling added, "but that's as far as we can go."
